You can change viewers, but not hubs. I have a guide on how to change hubs in a hacky way that leaves some residue and glitches though. Hopefully nofish adds in a clean way of switching hubs soon.

Hubs are intended to be merged. That's the whole point of the ZeroMe demo. ZeroMe is a viewer that merges content from ZeroMe hubs. The hubs themselves just hold different users/data/etc. You can pick and choose which hubs you want to view/follow/download/seed. So you could, say, only view Blue Hub posts and never bother to download any other hub. Perhaps someone makes a 'tech hub' and  people just post tech stuff in that hub.

But as of now, all the subs are near identical, just with users randomly thrown about. Since this is just a tech demo.
ZeroNet already supports this through 'optional files'. It'd just be a matter of implementing it into ZeroMe.

Just make a new site, and copy+paste the stuff in the ZeroMe folder. ZeroMe itself doesn't have a data folder, so you don't need to do anything else. You maybe want to delete the 'merged-zerome' folder though. And obviously change the content.json to refer to your own stuff.

Alternatively you could try to just modify the zerome content.json to have 'cloneable: true' and then clone it as usual.
You shouldn't need to join a hub. Since it'd just share the same data as ZeroMe. Just login, and stuff should pop up as usual. If you give me the link, I'll see if it's working.
Use Kaffiene to search through ZeroNet sites. It can also quickly search through the ZeroName directory: http://127.0.0.1:43110/kaffiene.bit/

For the sake of being able to help, I just made a quick zerome clone. I'm posting from it now, and following/activity feed work just fine. Posting works, and this is my comment test. The ZeroMe.db is indeed 100kb smaller, which is kinda suspicious, but I haven't noticed anything missing.

All I did to clone was copy+paste files, and edit the content.json to correctly point to the right site. I also made small tweaks like a css tweak (changed the background to be green), and adding Kaffie hub as a default. I didn't delete the db at all.

If your following/activity feed are busted, make sure you aren't double hubbing, since those are the most noticeable things to go haywire.

What we need is a torrent site that uses the hubs/merger feature. So that anyone reaching a cap can just use their own hub, or a hub with a huge limit. Hubs will also allow us to organize content, so that users only ever need to download categories/genres/etc. they're interested in.

@<tkarita/>: See my old posts. Hover over my user name on each post on my profile. You can see that after it gets old enough, red hub posts start to show.

As it stands, the backend works fine. There's no issues with this, and it'd work fine if repurposed for a torrent site. The problems occur due to the ZeroMe merger site not merging things properly. A properly made merger site wouldn't have any issues.
@Jayofthezero: Yea, all I did was literally just copy and paste the files to a new site and changed the 'address' bit in the content.json. Worked right out of the box.

@Jayofthezero: Do you know a better search engine? I made kaffiene and promote it because I want there to be a good well-known search engine for ZeroNet. If there's a better alternative, I'm happy to hear it.

@Jayofthezero: As an FYI, 'all.js' is a file generated by compiling the various .coffee files which make up ZeroMe's source code. It's not JS though, so if you're not familiar with coffeescript, it might make it harder to develop. If you look at the all.js, you can see comments of the .coffee file boundaries (where the files start/end). It might make it easier to develop your tweaks if you just fork the project on github and then pull the various official updates into your branch.
